thread.title: First Look: Skechers GOMeb Speed 4 & GOMeb Razor
thread.title_full: First Look: Skechers GOMeb Speed 4 & GOMeb Razor

title: First Look: Skechers GOMeb Speed 4 & GOMeb Razor
text:
Quote of the Day, motivation, and inspiration — every morning rundown 
Advice on training, nutrition, shoes, and more — every evening Enter your email address 
Privacy Policy | About Us 
The GOMeb Speed is a racing flat for Meb, and the GOMeb Razor is a training shoe — it’s a little bit bigger, offers a little bit more comfort, and provides extra cushioning. 
Previous versions of the GOMeb Speed used a pillar design underneath, with rubber pods. Now they’ve gone to a flat, full ground contact outsole with a very thin web of rubber that gives you some stretch, but eliminates those pods. 
Up top, you still get the knit upper and a really firm plastic clip at the bottom of the heel. It really locks in your heel and doesn’t allow it to move. But it’s really small, so it doesn’t create a lot of weight. There’s also a really quick drying, ventilated collar lining, a thin tongue (just enough to keep the laces off the top of your foot), and a very ventilated knit upper. Skechers is keeping things light for this fast shoe. 
By contrast, you get more midsole on the GOMeb Razor. The GOMeb Speed 4 has 4 millimeters of heel drop, while the GOMeb Razor has 8 millimeters, which is a more traditional offset. You also get thicker stacks in general, so there’s more material under the forefoot and more underneath the heel. 
You still get the knit upper in the Razor, and there’s a lot of ventilation as well. It’s just a little more stout, really hoping to help you on those longer training runs. 
The Skechers GOMeb Speed 4 retails for $130, and the Skechers GOMeb Razor retails for $110. We have both shoes on the feet of our wear testers now and we will have more detailed reviews soon on RunnersWorld.com.
